results.headline: Where Comedy and Complexity Meet

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of All the Best

results.summary_short: With all the giggles in Hindi cinema these days, it’s not surprising that an actor like Ajay Devgn should want in on the comedy fun.

results.headline: He Joins the Household, Then Leaves It Bloody

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Stepfather

results.summary_short: Dylan Walsh, of “Nip/Tuck,” plays a character who preys on attractive single women with children in “The Stepfather,” a clumsy remake of the 1987 cult thriller.

results.headline: Some of His Best Friends Are Beasts

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Where the Wild Things Are

results.summary_short: “Where the Wild Things Are” is an alternately perfect and imperfect if always beautiful adaptation of the Maurice Sendak children’s book.

results.headline: Love and Archaeology

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Opa!

results.summary_short: “Opa!” is a sweet, nontaxing movie set in the gorgeous Greek Isles.

results.headline: Resistance Fighter in the Making

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Little Traitor

results.summary_short: “The Little Traitor” is a muddled morality tale more interested in coming of age than getting of wisdom.

results.headline: Manhattan Is for Lovers: Two by Two by Two by ...

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of New York, I Love You

results.summary_short: In spite of some attempts at human and neighborhood variety, the stories in “New York, I Love You” have a self-conscious sameness.

results.headline: Her Place Is in the Home

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Maid

results.summary_short: The narrative design of “The Maid” is at once simple and complex.

results.headline: Revenge Is a Dish Best Served by a Robot

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Law Abiding Citizen

results.summary_short: The system fails a family man in “Law Abiding Citizen,” leading him to seek his own brand of justice.

results.headline: Hungry for Health
results.display_title: Food Beware: The French Organic Revolution

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Food Beware: The French Organic Revolution

results.summary_short: The documentary “Food Beware” takes a pragmatic, health-based approach.

results.headline: Action With Soul

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Black Dynamite

results.summary_short: It takes skill to make a movie bad on purpose, but movies that are bad by accident can be a lot more fun. That paradox is the main lesson of “Black Dynamite.”

results.headline: Early Laughs

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Believe: The Eddie Izzard Story

results.summary_short: Several things might strike you as odd about “Believe: The Eddie Izzard Story,” a documentary about the cross-dressing British comedian.

results.headline: A Hard Life, Especially as You’re Turning 80

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Adela

results.summary_short: The widely acclaimed Filipino actress Anita Linda gives a quietly transfixing performance as the title character of “Adela.”

results.headline: A Soccer Coach Divides and Doesn’t Conquer

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Damned United

results.summary_short: “The Damned United” is the rare sports movie that deals with humiliation and disappointment.

results.headline: Pupils With Antisocial Gifts

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of St. Trinian's

results.summary_short: “St. Trinian’s” is a stunningly witless revival of the infamous British film series about a girls’ boarding school.

results.headline: Playing Drums That Aren’t There

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Adventures of Power

results.summary_short: Your enjoyment of “Adventures of Power” will be proportional to your tolerance for the one-joke phenomenon of air drumming.

results.headline: A Man With a Camera and an Architectural Eye
results.display_title: Visual Acoustics: The Modernism of Julius Shulman

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Visual Acoustics: The Modernism of Julius Shulman

results.summary_short: Architecture aficionados, and design mavens in general, will have an agreeable time with “Visual Acoustics.”

results.headline: She’s a Big-Rig Driver on the Mommy Track

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trucker

results.summary_short: “Trucker” sometimes feels like a performance in search of a movie.

results.headline: A Couple Out of Order

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Peter and Vandy

results.summary_short: A contemporary Manhattan romance gets the muddled-timeline treatment in “Peter and Vandy.”

results.headline: Ghostbusters on a Budget: If Things Go Bump in the Night, Grab a Camera

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paranormal Activity

results.summary_short: “Paranormal Activity” is a crudely made, half-clever little frightener.

results.headline: Look but Don’t Touch: It’s All About the Hair

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Good Hair

results.summary_short: Spirited, probing and frequently hilarious, “Good Hair” coasts on the fearless charm of its front man and the eye-opening candor of its interviewees.
